content.text: The {working backwards} strategy, also known as {backsolving}, is one of the most powerful time-saving techniques on the ACT Math section. Instead of solving a problem algebraically from scratch, you test the answer choices to see which one works. This strategy is especially useful when the algebra looks complicated, but {answer choice testing} makes solving easy.

{Backsolving} means plugging in the answer choices to solve the problem. Instead of setting up equations and solving for x, you test each choice until you find the one that satisfies the conditions in the problem.

content.text: Follow these five steps to backsolve efficiently:

items.text: On the ACT, answer choices are always listed in ascending order (smallest to largest) or descending order (largest to smallest)
nested: Start with B or C (the middle value) - you can often eliminate 2-3 choices with one test
If C is too big, you know D and E are also too big
If C is too small, you know A and B are also too small

{Backsolving} isn't always the best strategy. Avoid it when:

items: Answer choices are algebraic expressions (not numbers)
The traditional algebra is very simple
Testing answer choices would be more work than solving directly
The problem has multiple variables and complex relationships
